description.text:
I designed this for a friend. It is designed to fit all the cards and pieces of the game and the game board inside the box. Will ask him to take some pictures of it when everything is in place.  
Also since my printer can only print 200x200mm I made these as smaller pieces. My friend also liked that idea since the boxes can be positioned more freely that way.  
EDIT: Made an update with lids that holds the small items in place during storage. The lids can be snapped in place on the bottom of each box when they're not in use.

Lightweight Tilt Gimbal for Boscam TR1.
--
I've created it for a FPV250 quadcopter to do FPV flights. The printed parts weight only 12 grams and in combination with a 6gr servo and the TR1 you'll get a complete FPV & video (recording at 1440x1080, 30 FPS) solution with only 70 gram!

Additional needed parts:
--
  • 2x 2mm nuts
  • 4x 2mm Screws
  • 2 bearings
  • 6gr Servo
    • Mounting order:

• Print all parts ;-)
  • Add a nut in each bracket part
  • Put the brackets to the camera
  • Add the back-part in place
  • Add 2mm screws to hold the parts together
  • Mount a 6gr Servo to the backpart
  • Add the bearings to the brackets
  • Add screws through bearings

This Monogram Cube is inspired by the cover art of Douglas Hofstadter's book "Godel, Escher, Bach." There are parameters for (up to) three letters and a typeface. The generated cube, if looked at from one of three angles, displays one of the letters. Open this 3D model in Customizer to select your own letters. More information is on my blog: http://netninja.com/2013/02/25/a-monogrammed-cube-for-you/

The easiest way to make a Monogram Cube is to load it up in Customizer and select your letters and typeface. If you are more of a tinkerer and want more control, you may download the *.scad file, edit the variables up top, and process it with OpenScad. There are two typefaces you can choose from. "Blocks" yields better results, but is more stylistic and block-like. It reminds me of some display typefaces from the 20s and 30s. It has smaller overhangs and is easier to print. "Alternate" results in more consistently letter-like, less stylized results, but has more overhangs and is harder to print. It also has a few more incompatible letters. Note that certain letter combinations don't work well, especially with the "alternate" typeface. Many letters you select, depending on which face they are on, will have
overhangs that will require a raft with supports. You might be able to skirt
around this with certain configurations of letters (for example, if only one of
the three letters has big overhangs) by rotating on the X or Y axis or even
flipping the whole block upside-down.

description.text: A model of a garage door that will open and close with the addition of a simple motor, Auduino Uno, Motor Shield and a 1/4-20 threaded rod and two 1/4 nuts. I made this as my first experiment with SolidWorks and 3D Printing. My company, Telguard, is launching a Z-Wave Garage Door Opener and I thought it would be easier to demo a micro garage door than a full size one. I couldn't find a small demo to purchase so I built this one. The open/close logic is very basic so, if you feel inclined, improved it and send it back my way. I will be posting photos, video and the Arduino sketch later. I am printing a new one now because the first one went to a trade show.

description.text:
I had this stepper motor in my house and I didn´t know what to do with it so I decided to make a syringe pump as I like to call it, to use with solder paste. Since I didn't know how to get a even flow of the paste I design this little tool. It works with a stepper motor, this motor move back and forward pushing the air out of the syringe to another syringe with to tact switches (Forward, Backward) in order to activate the motor.
Probably I'm not being clear on the explanation but, I'll be posting news, updates. All comments will be highly appreciated. UPDATE: Dec/13/2015 17:45
=
Here you have thelink for all the STL and original files.
https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7dtMeeMPK5rfjcyQl9yN09IMC1pZm5GZ0NvZGg1ZW12anlyczRuNEVUWWVOU2dvUWQ1bGM UPDATE: Nov/12/2014 0:03
=
I have uploaded some pictures of the printed parts.
Still one missing, I have to print it out.
Assembling video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M6tPrioTTM4 UPDATE: Jan/05/2015 10:28
=
Thanks to cardej2 I realize that the STL of the motor mount was missing or missing. I downloaded but, is had a problem with various softwares to open it. I have repaired the mount and uploaded.

Bill of materials 2) x 3 mm smooth rod. (136 mm long)
1) x 3 mm threaded rod. (136 mm long)
1) x 28BYJ-48 Stepper Motor (I'm using the 5V one).
1) x Set of plastic parts
1) x 5 cc Syringe OPTIONAL
A table to place the pump so it doesn't move. ASSEMBLING INSTRUCTIONS
Here you'll find a very useful video of how to assemble the pump.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M6tPrioTTM4 I haven't tested the pump yet, but I'll be posting the results of it.
I did a little search on the web and I think you can use a 10cc syringe without having to modify the files or even filing the plastic parts.

description.text: This is a support to put a 2.5HDD on a Xbox360 slim hard drive bay. The drive could be either a hacked 2.5hdd SATA drive so it works on the 360, or a drive taken out of an older model (non slim) XBox 360 hard drive enclosure.

Just place your drive inside the printed object and then insert the whole on your 360 slim hard drive bay. 
The support mount has screw holes designed on it so the hard drive can be solidly locked into the mount for added security. I didn't end up using it as printing this object on my Makerbot CupCake the drive snapped tightly on the mount thus avoiding the need for mounting screws.

Please help me populate this map with 3D printing business around the world to make this a great resource for helping people find out about 3D printing.
This map is part of my Senior Thesis Project as a Graphic Designer. I need a list of businesses that have any relation with 3D printing. These can business can be about 3D printer manufactures, Stores that sell 3D printed products, or anything else that is related to 3D printing or printers. This list is also for Consumer and Profestional 3D printers and services so please include the professional side as well. 
My goal is to populate it with locations so you can see if there is a location near you related to 3D printing. I want to bring the awareness to 3D printing to the forefront so we can soon know the full potential of what 3D printing can really do.

http://goo.gl/maps/VlXYL To add locations to the map is not difficult, however you will need to be logged into your gmail account to add locations. Once you are signed in and located on the map page, click the edit button located on the left hand side. From here you are ready to add to the map. You can either hand enter any location data and information or you can search and add pre-existing google company locations to the map. If you see anything that is missing please add as much company information as you can and as much location data as you can. DO NOT delete the information and instructions on the map so other people can know what to do and add to it. If there is any online only companies that you may think I will need then please send me an email to [email protected]

comments.text: thanks everyone for adding to the map.  dont forget that this will be a great resource one day so we need everything related to 3d printing and not just people who make 3d printers.  I would like to also include businesses that sell 3d printers all over the world, and businesses that sell printed products.

title: Laser Pointer Rocking Mount for ZWobble Compensation

description.text: Use this rocking laser pointer mount in place of a dial gauge in conjunction with the z-wobble calibration feature in the latest firmware to measure and eliminate ZWobble (periodic banding) in prints on the Solidoodle 2.

The primary cause of periodic "wobble" in prints on the Solidoodle 2--particular at high resolution--is due to periodic non-linear movement of the print bed when moving in the Z-direction. The latest Solidoodle firmware ( at https://github.com/mlaws/solidoodle2-marlin ) adds a new "Z-Wobble" compensation feature that allows you to define a custom compensation curve. The firmware applies the inverse of this curve when moving the bed, leading to virtually wobble-free prints when properly calibrated. Since the firmware automatically scales the input values when defining the custom compensation curve, one can use a rocking laser pointer to hugely amplify the bed movement, easily measure the position with a ruler or tape measure, then directly enter these enlarged values to define a compensation curve. Instructions (from http://www.soliwiki.com/Calibration_of_the_Z_wobble)

  • If necessary, install a version of the firmware with z-wobble compensation

  • Print the laser rocker, making any modifications necessary to fit your laser pointer

  • Home the print head and fit the rocker on the bed with a laser pointer aimed at a sheet of paper taped to a wall about 10-20 ft away. Rest the point of the rocker near the end of the bed and hook the far end underneath the near x-axis rod.

  • Send the following codes to home the print head and clear any previous compensation, and move the bed down one full rotation of the z-axis threaded rod (1.411mm):
    • M97 A0
    G28
    G1 Z1.411

  • To avoid any backlash, start measurements from this location (one revolution away from home) instead of at zero. Undo any backlash by manually stepping the bed up (head down) a few .1mm steps and then back down (head up) the same number of steps.

  • Mark the laser point (base point), then make an additional 14 marks, continuing to move the bed down (head up) .1mm between each mark.

  • Measure the distance (in mm or any unit) of each of the 14 marks from the initial point.

  • For convenience, copy the following gcode into a text file entering the 14 numbers into the indicated spaces (or edit the attached example gcode file):
    • M97 A0 ; turn off any previous wobble compensation
    M96 ; print settings
    M97 W1.411 P0 ; set period to 1/18th inch
    M97 Z0.0 L0 ; enter deflection measurements in last column
    M97 Z0.1 L[distance between 1st and base point]
    M97 Z0.2 L[distance between 2nd and base point]
    M97 Z0.3 L[distance between 3rd and base point]
    M97 Z0.4 L[distance between 4th and base point]
    M97 Z0.5 L[distance between 5th and base point]
    M97 Z0.6 L[distance between 6th and base point]
    M97 Z0.7 L[distance between 7th and base point]
    M97 Z0.8 L[distance between 8th and base point]
    M97 Z0.9 L[distance between 9th and base point]
    M97 Z1.0 L[distance between 10th and base point]
    M97 Z1.1 L[distance between 11th and base point]
    M97 Z1.2 L[distance between 12th and base point]
    M97 Z1.3 L[distance between 13th and base point]
    M97 Z1.4 L[distance between 14th and base point]
    M96 ; print compensation curve

  • To send the compensation values to the printer, just load the gcode file above and "print" it. The M96 command at the bottom should print the defined curve, which will typically take the form of a sinusoidal-like wave. As these settings are not persistent (i.e. will be lost when the Solidoodle USB cable is unplugged) you should do this at the start of each session or may wish to add it to your slicing app's starting gcode.

  • (optional) use the laser rocker again with compensation enabled to verify that bed movements are now equally spaced.
    • If recalibration is ever necessary in the future (if printer is jostled or the stop screw changed), restart at step 3.

comments.author: FatalDischarge

comments.text: I've been watching this in Soliforum and I just want to know if this still a reliable solution.
comments.author: FatalDischarge

comments.text: The wobble-compensation?  Absolutely.  IMHO It's the easiest way to definitively fix any periodic error in the layer height because it does so regardless of the actual hardware cause.  It just requires a way to measure the non-linearity in the z-carriage movement and the laser rocker does that.  The updated software does the rest by inverting the measured non-linearity curve when sending z-coordinates to the printer.
comments.author: FatalDischarge

comments.text:
I only ask because it seems that near the end of a couple of those discussions, it sounded like some were starting to have doubts.
Do I just add this to the "start code" menu in the "g-code editor" tab in Repetier, after I find my laser pointer and get the measurements?
comments.author: tealvince

comments.text: You can do that (and that's what I did at first).  But now I just load the completed separate code file into pronterface and "Print" it (i.e. send it to the printer) before starting any printing.  The compensation settings will then stay active until the printer logic board is powered down or reset, so you only have to send it before the first print.  I did, however, add an "M96" command to my start gcode so that whenever a start a print, it dumps out the current compensation curve so I know that compensation is on.

description.text: This is a completely modular test tube rack. You have the ability to change the racks height, the diameter of the holes, and the amount of tubes it can hold. The main advantage of this design is the ability for it to fit every size of test tube, and any amount of tubes thus eliminating the need to dig for a particular size of test tube rack. Tube racks of similar size go anywhere from $10 for smaller ones to over $60+ for the larger ones. The cost of printing one of these customized racks is for around $4 for a smaller one, and a minimal amount more for very large racks. This price can further be reduced by using less than 25% infill.

description.text: This is a simple geometric model of a GoPro camera on its basic camera mount, intended to be used during other designs to ensure mounting clearances for a GoPro.

Include this model in your own OpenSCAD designs when you want to include a mount point for a GoPro camera. This model is just barely larger than an actual GoPro, making fit-by-inspection possible. Here's an example script that generated the picture of the GoPro trio, left-to-right:

translate([100,0,0]) goPro(15);
goPro(0);
translate([-100,0,0]) goPro(-15);

author: olszewskihm

description.text:
Recently, our university network has become very unstable.
I developed a windows version of the modeling web service.
Please, visit http://facebook.com/lithopia for download and further updates.
Thanks. JM

After realized making things with 3D printers is a very attractive job, I wanted to contribute to this community as a programmer.
I built this web service with my graduate students so that you can design and 3D-print high quality cylinder lithophanes in an easy way.
We hope you enjoy this! http://maker.dongguk.edu/cylinder_lithophane/index.html
  • The sample STL file was made with 768x180 resolution image for faster upload. For real printing, I recommend making your own lamp with 1024x240 or higher resolution images. Currently, system allows 1536x360 resolution maximum in a performance reason.
  • Smoothing option smooths the printing pattern so that it can be printed without support. We used 5 in general.

Use web browser to open the web service at http://210.94.199.44/litho_client/index.html and drag-and-drop an image you want to carve on a cylinder. You may want to customize some parameters like cylinder radius, print thickness, etc.

comments.text: I thought the same thing but I tried that and the image does not come out sharp enough to be be recognized.  It seems that one of the jobs of the base, is to defuse the light so it is more even when passing through the image layers.  When you change the side the image is on (rough edges with image on the inside) the light passes through the image but the base layer (even if it is very thin) defuses it and smooths the transitions too much. It is like looking at the image through a thick fog.  I tried it with the layer so thin that some to the "bright" spots instead of being thin were just non existent and it still had the same problem.

description.text:
Mini model of the Parthenon made in Morphi app.
www.morphiapp.com This is a minimalist model of the Parthenon (Temple of Athena) in Athens, Greece. In Morphi, users of all skill levels can make 3D printable objects on the go using touch, without wifi or a mouse. Download the app for free for iPad and IPad mini on the App Store. https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/morphi/id833530351?mt=8 Coming soon for Android! Copyright 2014-2015, The Inventery, Inc.

Print this model or make your own in Morphi!
Depending on your printer, you may want to adjust the speed at various points during the print cycle. For instance, you may want to increase the speed slightly when you get to the layer above the columns and you may want to reduce the speed for printing the triangular prism at the top.

title: Geo Bracelet 01
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Modeled in Maya while sitting at a coffee shop near Stanford (man did I feel like I fit some sort of stereotype).  After working on "Geo Necklace 01", I wanted to try something slightly more complicated.  This "bracelet" is two combined tori:  The base is 8-sided, the top is 6-sided.  No overhang issues, but I did have to pick out some interior loose filament.  Spray-painted it two-tone blue/red.

Successfully printed in 'natural' PLA with "medium" settings in Makerware:
Extruded at 210, HBP off, no supports.
2 shells, 10% infill (presuming there is any infill at all).
Took 50 minutes to print, used 13g of PLA.

description.text: yegahD extruder. developed for my golemC printer but customized to fit mendel, BiBone and two screw vertical carts

so it brakes in customizer - AGAIN! works in openSCAD fine though. I will look for the cause soon, in mean time just download an tweak in openSCAD. don't hesitate to drop me a line, I know the code is messy and full of variables, help me make it better by pointing out the most needed ones.
  • one block print
  • lightweight - 3x 6x13x5 bearings
  • designed for double mount
  • milled bolt with grooved idler provide ultra strong (10kg plus @ 1.75mm ABS) grip with little filament deformation
  • visible drive bolt, easy to inspect, easy to clean (it does not tend mill away filament, unless nozzle blockage)
  • almost everything parametric
    • it's using bolt: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53955 you can try and print the idler but it will probably break in near future, turned out of POM or PA6 is better idea. yes, I overdone it with number of params, well they just build up over couple of moths :) default is mendel mount, 16mm j-head, 1.75mm filament in 4mm ptfe guide, 22mm custom grooved idler. just find the variables you want to change and customize. if it refuses to render properly i will try to fix it so feel free to feedback me plenty :) WARNING! still testing (about 5 kilos with no problems whatsoever), feel free to join or wait a week or two for stable version see homepage http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Yegah
    see derivative http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38874 (if you need vitamins, he's the dealer )

author: sirion

title: DNA Ball and Stick Model Base Pair

description.text: This is a model of a DNA base pair that I recently turned into a 3D print. This model was made similar to my previous models using VMD and Tinkercad. I built it so you can print out multiple copies and glue them together to make a scaled double helix. At the current time, I only have the one base pair, with is AT. I tried flipping it over to make it TA, but it seemed to skew the helix, so I just put mine together as though it was polyA. I think it worked out quite well, and broke out the paints to put 5 of them together. I think it needs about 10 to make it really show the major and minor groove well, but that will have to come later. I am posting it here, and also put together some tutorials on YouTube in case someone wants to see how we go about doing these.

I built this a little bit too small in TinkerCad. My suggestion is that if you download it, you scale the entire thing up to 150%, which is what I did so you can get a decent print. It is quite robust. It does need a raft, but should not need any supports. I made it so you can easily remove the supports. You will need to do a little bit of trimming if you want to put multiple components together (similar to what we did with cellulose), but then it glues together nicely with Model Cement. I printed it on an older MakerBot II at medium quality level.

comments.text:
This is really awesome! I'm going to print a ton of these and hang them form the ceiling.
Could you post a version without supports? I'd like to try my own hand at it. They are easy to remove, but it's a very tedious process. My printer may be able to print the model with supports with more of a tapered tip or cone like Meshmixer creates.

title: How to install an Inductive Proximity Sensor for Auto Bed Leveling

description.text: I had a lot of trouble getting mine to work right; this should clear things up. I used this probe (http://goo.gl/WsFJGQ) - it is a LJ12A3-4-Z/BY. You can buy one from Printrbot, but they are much more expensive there. You will need to regulate the signal to 5V, but the probe will need at least 6V. I plugged the probe's power into the main input on RAMPS and used two 10k resistors to regulate the voltage as shown in the diagram above. This video (by Thomas Sanladerer) will further explain how to get things working: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EcGFLwj0pnA. Here is a mount for a Greg's extruder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:491105 You can also reference firmware configured for an inductive proximity sensor here: https://github.com/quillford/Marlin/blob/Marlin_v1/Marlin/Configuration.h.

comments.text:
​I have a couple of questions to be cleared about wiring. First of all, as I understood from @mickeypop 's sayings in here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Enable-Auto-Leveling-for-your-3D-Printer-Marlin-Fi/?ALLSTEPS , S pin of the RAMPS is "Signal in" pin and it needs to take in 5V voltage. PNP and NPN proximity sensors are different basically as the Black wire could be used as "sinking" or "sourcing" the current as mentioned here:
http://www.schneider-electric.co.uk/en/faqs/FA142566/

comments.text: The sensor is a small PCB with two screw holes, and a connector for 5V, Gnd, and analog out. There is an adjustment pot on the back to set the fixed offset range (like 1 to 8cm), hence no need to adjust the height physically. Depending on the height of your printer bed you can adjust the pot until you get a linear range reading between 0 and 5V. You can set your firmware to trigger on any analog voltage you like. This sensor was designed for a large format printer to detect paper jamming. I can sell you one cheap on eBay to get you started.

title: Makerbot Mustaches plates for S, M and L sizes

description.text:
I've been printing a huge amount of mustaches using my Makerbot. I made a few modifications to the original two piece model by gianteye to be able to print it in different sizes easily.
The S size is a scaled down mustache (75 % of the original size I think) with both pieces merged into one single piece which fits nicely in the Makerbot platform.
The M size is the same size as the original by gianteye but I arranged the pieces to be able to print them both at once.
The L size is a enlarged version as big as the Makerbot platform allows. I also modified the distance between the two pieces that hold the mustache in the nose to put them closer.

Print the stl files for the size of your choice:
small size: Mustache-S.stl estimated print time: 10 min
medium size: Mustache-M.stl estimated print time: 20 min (not sure)
large size: Mustache-Left-L.stl and Mustache-Right-L.stl estimated print time: 17 min each.

description.text: I took http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9460 and used the gear4a that imports well into openSCAD to build a coupler that an 11 tooth pinon gear can be inserted into.

My 2004 RX-8's climate control fan knob broke right on its stem. Cost of a new one is like fifty bucks! Gluing it back together is difficult because of the small surfaces and the fact that it's HDPE. So I made this little adapter that uses a friction fit on the remaining bits to re-create the necessary mounting hardware. It may fit other years, not sure.

Here's an attempt at a step-by-step. Watch my YouTube video to get a slightly better idea of what's going on: http://youtu.be/Ira08ukeK8A 1) You need to clean up the remaining bits of the knob's stem (or stalk, whatever you wanna call it). Look down the D-shaft. You'll notice a small X inside the D-shaft. Trim the D-shaft down flush with that X.
2) Print this out. I used 0.4 wall, 0.4 top/bottom, external supports, and 15% infill on Cura. I'd recommend using 0.6 wall/top/bottom if I were to re-print this; my print has gaps in the top layer as you can see.
3) Go to your car. Push the print onto the shaft.
4) Line up the knob and push it onto the print.
5) Enjoy your newfound control over the fan!

description.text:
This is a water bottle cage for a bicycle. 
It is separated into three parts for easy printing. The two rings insert into the bar, and all three pieces are screwed into place at the mounting points on the bike. The bottom of the bar has been reinforced to prevent breaking.

• Print one of the bars and two of the rings. All three pieces are included in the "full plate" STL. I used a relatively high infill so that the components would not break while riding.

  • Insert the blocky parts of the two rings into the bar, making sure that the holes line up. Rings work equally effective pointed up or pointed down.

  • Screw the full assembly into the bike's frame at the mounting points.

This is an improvement on babozor318's original leatherman holster design, which was originally inspired by an episode of Tested's One day builds with Adam Savage.
I started by adding the block to the back and cutting out an angled belt loop. The angle just makes it a little easier to reach in all circumstances. I printed out the original with my belt loop added and it wan't even close to being able to fit the leatherman wave. After measuring the printed case, leatherman, and the stl in rhino, I decided to stretch it out by 2mm to accomodate the thickness of the leatherman. Now it fits perfectly.
I've done 2 versions, a Right Handed and a Left Handed. The only difference being the angle of the belt loop. At some point I'll upload a version that fits wider belts.
Edit: The current version's belt loop accepts belts up to 33mm wide.
Link to the original designers files: https://github.com/babozor318/leathermanWaveHolster
Link to the Adam Savage podcast episode that inspired the project: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Et-JvYrQ84o

I printed it out in ABS on my Airwolf HD with 0.2mm layers and 90% infill. I printed it upright, on a raft, and used supports at a 65 degreee threshold (no support for overhangs shallower than 65 degrees). This ensured that there were no supports inside the belt loop - they aren't necessary in there.
I strongly recommend doing an acetone vapour bath to strengthen this part if you print it out of ABS. It also makes it look great.

This piece is a ring to be 3d printed [and to wear in your finger]. It has one of Robert Ammann's golden rhombohedra [ca. 1975]. These are very interesting regular polihedra, that have the property of packing space in aperiodic tessellations. They are related to Roger Penrose's rhombi, that tesselate 2d space aperiodically as well. Penrose's rhombi [or rhombuses] can be found in the golden rhombohedra [spatial] diagonals. The faces of Ammann's rhombohedra [of course all of them are the same being a regular polihedrum] are golden rhombi, i.e., their diagonals are in harmonic proportion [1/fi]. Some links here:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Ammann
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penrose_tiling Even if this design is not related to our main line of work [tcf], i decided to upload it because the cf project is rather slow these days, and i thought this would be a nice design to share for the first day of the year! The interior diameter of the ring in this version is 20 mm. This means it will fit a woman with large hands or a man with small ones. Svq is the airport acronym for sevilla, spain, where i printed the ring, at the Digital Fabrication Laboratory of the School of Architecture [University of Seville]. Credits [cc-by-sa] should be: the commons factory / jose perez de lama aka osfa

The files uploaded are the rhinoceros 3d file and two versions of the stl file - ascii and binary - i am actually not very sure about which of these two is more convenient. title: Replacement runners for Ikea RAST chest of drawers

description.text:
The plastic runners on Ikea RAST chests of drawers break very easily, leading to stuck drawers and frustration. This Thing allows you to replace them with something better.
Many thanks to Dr Mike Prior-Jones (@mrpj100) and to Stuart at Glasgow MAKlab for their help with this project.

• Download the SVG file. The SCAD and STL files are from an earlier approach, and are included for interest; they should provide 3D-printable replacements for the existing runners, but I haven't actually tried them. Let me know if they work!
  • Laser-cut the SVG file out of 8mm plastic sheet. HDPE would be best, because of its low friction; I used some scrap acrylic, which worked fine.
  • Countersink the screw holes.
  • Remove the drawers and the existing runners.
  • Remove the plastic knobs from the inside of the drawers - since the new runners are not hollow, there's nowhere for them to go.
  • Mark where the holes need to go on the wood.
  • Using an awl or reamer, make starter holes for the screws.
  • Screw in the new runners using 20mm size 4 self-tapping wood screws (I used these: http://www.screwfix.com/p/screw-tite-prodrive-csk-4-x-20mm-pack-of-200/57300).
  • Slide the drawers back into the chest.
  • Rejoice in your new freely-sliding chest of drawers.

Update 02.25.13 proof of concept looks good, needs some tweaks. Gonna add a small cylinder across all 3 hinges at the rear to insert a pin for a lock/stop. Probably get rid of the plates sticking off the rear (was extra motor support). Have to wait until the weekend, busy busy. 03-02-13 update:
made lots of little tweaks. tried adding nut traps, but the force was not with me today- (I'm just learning sketchup). I laid the revised parts out in a nest including belt clamps, and added pads because I've been getting a lot of curling. I hope this helps. I also added the updated sketchup file if anyone wants it. 03-03-13:
Added nut traps. 03-07-13:
Finalized design. This is the print that I am going to try and use. I deleted the older files, as they were experimental to begin with.
The updated parts are in the "nest" sketchup file, the other one has the extruder models in it.

I'm going to start vertically, 2 shells, 25% infill, no supports

remixed_from.author: Ablapo
remixed_from.title: Servo direct connector (surface melt) - femur, thigh bone

description.text:
This hip joint for walking robots can be used for metal geared servos. The other printed leg parts of the pictures can be found in the ancestor things:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53120
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:51425 At the moment I don't know how much weight this part can carry. If you see the printed part bending, then you can use the optional lower clamp part.
I added a picture including the coxa part from tmbg's "3DOF Mini Quadruped" to compare the dimensions of my optional, experimental clamp version.

Adjust the parameters using OpenSCAD for best performance. Then print the part with at least 3 perimeters. More details on surface melting: www.thingiverse.com/thing:51425
Make sure there is a small hole in the gear trap. Then heat up the inner surface with a torch tool and press a metal geared servo into that melted surface and the gear trap.
To heat up the surface of the printed part I'm using an alcohol torch from Buffalo. You can squeeze that alcohol filled plastic bottle to have a tiny flame tip.
Secure the servo with a screw. There should be no gap between the printed part and the servo's body.
This heat method is not recommended with nylon geared servos. Resin may be a better way for nylon geared servos. Next step is to connect the leg to that printed coxa part. That end is used as a clamp and should sit very tight. Secure that end with another screw. The experimental version shows the coxa part together with an optional clamp part. Probably you will not need this clamp part. This clamp stl-file is for servos with a height of 27.5 mm.

title: Dexcom G4 Receiver case with port protector

description.text:
Case for the Dexcom G4 Receiver combined with a mirco USB adapter to protect the fragile port. Adapter is a 90 degree RIGHT micro usb male to micro usb female adapter bought of Ebay (usually sold in left/right pairs). This adapter can probably be bought from alot of places. Make sure you get the one with MICRO usb connectors and not MINI. NOTICE: Please be very, very carefull when inserting/removing your Dexcom Receiver using this case. Any deviation in case/adapter/receiver dimensions could damage your receiver. It might also be a good idea to glue the adapter to make sure it does not move. If it is not a perfect fit - do not use it! Use at own risk. Can be used together with this Moto G (G1) Nightscout rig:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:576735 Updated 4 jun 2015:
v1.2 more minor updates for improved durability.

description.text:
This is my second revision of the micro h-quadcopter I have been designing. I've made a few modifications in order to improve the rigidity and durability of the frame. The arms are still angled outwards at 25 degrees in order to take on loads more axially in a crash. The motor holes are designed for the Turnigy 2900KV motors and the controller board posts are designed for 50mm boards with 45mm hole spacing. You can find a build log of this quadcopter on my website:
http://www.rctutor.org/3d-printed-quadcopter.html A brief overview and some flight footage of the quadcopter can be found here:
http://youtu.be/9UvrB3ZtkFE Also, flight footage of KapteinKuk using this frame design:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4bLkVTeQGqs

Thanks to the magic of openSCAD and parameterization, I only had to change four variables to print out the bracket to fit this new application. It worked on the first try. I had to change the height, width, and length to match the USB charger. Because this device is much smaller than the previous design, I also had to reduce the corner radius from 3 to 1.5 to deal with the smaller dimensions. http://www.amazon.com/Charging-Desktop-Station-SmartIC-Technology/dp/B00L2SBZ80
Original model taken from WoW, all rigts reserved to Blizzard inc. For personal, non-commercial use only!

description.text:
A friend asked me to make the most obnoxious disc I could for him so here it is! I have yet to test the actual disc's flight characteristics but after an entire day of R&D with different whistle chambers sizes, shapes and what not I do believe that this should work. I'll update later on with a report of its success.
Update 1: Alright so it kind of just makes a bit of noise, like a wiffle ball. I did whip it right into the outside of my building and it gave it a nice dent, however it's not really any serious damage. I could see with a springier material, say nylon 645 or 618, or NinjaFlex it could actually be a viable disc. I'll upload a different model later on with some modified whistle chambers to see if I can improve the whistle.
Update 2: I've made the disc closer to standard size. I've also changed the profile a bit and made a change to the inlet of the whistle. I'll update on the success of these changes.
Update 3: I changed the name to be a bit more truthful.
I am printing this from ABS with 0.22 mm layer height and a 0.35 mm nozzle. Medium speeds and a 25% honeycomb infill because I didn't want it to be too heavy, weak, or use too much material.

comments.author: pjdonovan21

comments.text: As an avid frolfer, it's a pretty fair disc. Flies reasonably straight, and if printed with 100% infill, and a heavier material it carries a fair distance, however it is by no means a driver. Mid-range at most, like 25-30 yard throws are the norm that I've gotten with reasonable accuracy. Longer distances are possible but I haven't put in too much time with it. However, it does manage to make a little bit of noise as I had hoped, just not a very loud noise.

an improved spool mount for mendelmax printer with bracing

after getting frustrated with my spool falling off my bearing mount for the third time I figured it was time for a better system.  There are several available for the mendelmax but the one i liked best was thing:21547. this is a derivative thing:21547 with some added bracing so it does not wobble or break off. The two braces are set at about a 60 degree overhang. I was able to print without any support material at .3 layer height and a .5 nozzle just beautifully.

Sometimes you just have too much "stuff" in your refrigerator. Whether you're a grill master with multiple sauces and marinades needing real estate in your fridge, or simply someone wanting to add an extra layer of organization inside to your fridge, this rotating organizer can ease your pain.
The concept uses a Lazy Susan bearing setup to deliver smooth rotational operation. The base, top, and fastener cap is designed to be printed out of ABS, while the bearing cage is to be laser cut from 1/10" acrylic. The design uses ten 1/4" stainless steel ball bearings, as seen in the figures attached to the entry.
The first revision of the Lazy Organizer allows for quick implementation into any current model refrigerator, all the way down to the small dorm room models. While small and compact, the Lazy Organizer is the perfect size to help organize the various small items that tend to get lost in the midst of the "refrigerator chaos".

Yet another filament spool that you can cut out of wood or acrylic. Uses CNC captive nut joinery. One novelty here is the adjustability of the tightness of the filament mounting based on slot choice at assembly time. The staggered rows of slots give a wide variety of mounting positions.

I cut this out of 1/4" plywood with my oversized shapeoko. Necessary Hardware (based on default parameters):
6 x (10mm M5 bolt + nut + washer) Optional:
2 x 608 bearing Press bearings in. Choose the set of holes for the rib bolts based on desired tightness of ribs against filament. The default parameters were chosen to be about the same size as a 1kg makerbot spool. They are untested since my prototype (in the photo) used less reasonable dimensions.

title: Makergear M2 Z axis hard end stop

description.text: The Makergear M2 has a hard end stop on the X and Y axis, but the Z axis can be commanded to push into the switch and mess up the Z adjustment, this thing clips on to the Z axis guide rod and acts as a stop.

I printed this thing in PLA using .25mm layers at 20% infill (standard settings) on an M2. I ran the STL through Netfab so it is clean and ready to slice. It's 23mm tall for my setup, you may need a taller or shorter version, just scale the Z axis for your application. It easily snaps on the guide rod.

description.text:
Lake George, NY, narrows region
Created using a free program called Maperitive, which downloads elevation data from the open street map project. I then import the models into sketchup and do some post processing in meshlab and netfabb.
I like to print these on edge.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:276359 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=276359

Using the following options: glassThickness = 3.1
mountTopThickness = 2
hotBedSizeY = 214
hotBedSizeX = 214
glassSizeY = 200.1
glassSizeX = 200.1
hotBedMountPointY = 2.4
hotBedMountPointX = 2.4
mountSize = 15
hotBedMountPointDiameter = 3.1
mountBorderThickness = 2
mountGlassBorderThickness = 4
hotBedThickness = 2.2

Designed for 1/2 inch PVC pipe, Schedule (SCH) 10 thickness (2.1mm).
Print with at least 0.8mm shell thickness, and maybe 110% filament extrusion.
Hopefully it won't leak.
